metadata.title: Yolo v5 Object Detection Tutorial | by Joos Korstanje | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Object Detection is a task in Artificial Intelligence that focuses on detecting objects in images. Yolo V5 is one of the best available models for Object Detection at the moment. The great thing…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: You can follow along with the full notebook over here.

all_paragraphs: Object Detection is a task in Artificial Intelligence that focuses on detecting objects in images. Yolo V5 is one of the best available models for Object Detection at the moment. The great thing about this Deep Neural Network is that it is very easy to retrain the network on your own custom dataset.
In this article, I will cover how to train a Yolo V5 Object Detection model. I will focus on how to get started quickly and easily, rather than on tuning the hyper parameters of the model.
You can follow along with the full notebook over here.
To train a custom Yolo V5 model, these are the steps to follow:
To train a Yolo V5 model, a few things need to be downloaded from the internet.
In a Notebook, the easiest is to download and setting up your environment using terminal commands directly from your notebook, as follows:
This will create a folder called ‘yolov5’ on your machine. This folder will contain everything you need further on, including pre-trained weights for the model, and a specific directory structure.
Yolo V5 runs on Torch, which may sometimes be complicated to install. If you struggle here, you can move to a Kaggle or Colab notebook: those generally work well for this installation.
Yolo V5 needs a very specific set up of data folders in order to work.

You need to create a folder called data at the same level as your yolov5 folder. In this data folder you need to create a folder for images and a folder for labels. Inside each of them, you make a folder for train data and a folder for validation data.
If files are not placed in the right directory, you are likely to encounter errors later on.

The images have to be directly in the image folders. Training images in the data/images/train folder and validation images in the data/images/valid folder. The names of the images have to be simply unique names with a .jpg (or another format).
The labels have to be in the data/labels/train/ or in the data/labels/valid. The name of the labels file has to be the same name as the image, but with “.txt” instead of “.jpg”.
The bounding boxes have to be listed as one bounding box per line, with on that line:

Standardization is done by dividing the number of pixels by the total number of pixels of the image. So a bounding box on pixel (10, 20) with a width of 30x40 on a picture of size (100, 100) would be standardized to (0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4).
The number of lines of the label file is the number of bounding boxes in one image. The number of label files is the number of images.
To start training a Yolo V5 model you need two YAML files.
The first YAML is to specify:
The second YAML is to specify the whole model, but for getting started I’d advise changing only the first line, “nc”, to have the right number of classes.
You can put those YAML files anywhere you want because you will reference the complete path later on.
Training is done using the train.py terminal command, which you can execute from your notebook.

There are multiple hyper-parameters that you can specify, for example, the batch size, the number of epochs, and the image size. You then specify the locations of the two yaml files that we just created above. You also specify a name, which is important later on to find your results.
Running this line will create a sub-folder in yolov5 that contains the weights of this trained model, which you can then reuse in step 5.
Those folders will always be created in the same directory: yolov5/runs/exp0_yourname/…
Exp0 will augment to exp1 etc when you rerun the “train” command.

Now for the final phase, you will want to detect objects on unseen photos. This is done using the terminal command detect.py, which will generate a new folder with outputs. You can either generate pictures with the bounding boxes drawn on them, or you can generate text files with the locations of the bounding boxes.
You can then find your output in the folder yolov5/inference/output/. There will be annotated images and .txt files with the predicted bounding boxes.
I hope this tutorial was useful, thanks for reading!
